abstract.text: Access the user’s contacts, and format and localize contact information.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: The Contacts framework provides Swift and Objective-C APIs to access the user’s contact information. Because most apps read contact information without making any changes, this framework is optimized for thread-safe, read-only usage.
The Contacts framework is available on all Apple platforms, and replaces the Address Book framework in iOS and macOS.
The contact class (
) is a thread-safe, immutable value object of contact properties, such as the contact’s name, image, and phone numbers.
The contact class is like
in that it has a mutable subclass,
, you can use to modify contact properties. For contact properties that can have multiple values, such as phone numbers and email addresses, the framework uses an array of

objects. The labeled value class is a thread-safe, immutable tuple of labels and values. Labels describe each value to the user, allowing differentiation, such as home and work phone numbers. The Contacts framework provides some predefined labels and you can create your own custom labels.

code: // Create a mutable object to add to the contact.
// Store the profile picture as data.
let homeEmail = CNLabeledValue(label: CNLabelHome, value: "john@example.com" as NSString)
let workEmail = CNLabeledValue(label: CNLabelWork, value: "j.appleseed@icloud.com" as NSString)
birthday.year = 1988  // (Optional) Omit the year value for a yearless birthday.

inlineContent.text: The Contacts framework helps you format and localize contact information. For example, you can correctly format a contact name (using
) or format an international postal address (using
You can display localized object property names and predefined labels based on the current locale setting of the device. Many objects in the Contacts framework, such as
, include the
method, which lets you get the localized version of a key name. In addition, the
class includes the
method, which lets you get the localized label for the predefined labels in the Contacts framework.
You can fetch contacts using the contact store (

), which represents the user’s Contacts database. The contact store encapsulates all I/O operations and is responsible for fetching and saving contacts and groups. Because the contact store methods are synchronous, it’s best practice to use them on background threads. If necessary, you can safely send immutable fetch results back to the main thread.
The Contacts framework provides several ways to constrain contacts that return from a fetch, including predefined predicates and the
property.
provides predicates for filtering the contacts you want to fetch. For example, to fetch contacts that have the name
Appleseed
, use
and pass in
Note that the Contacts framework doesn’t support generic and compound predicates.
You can use
to limit the contact properties that you fetch. For example, if you want to fetch only the given name and the family name of a contact, you specify those contact keys in a
array.
To fetch a contact using both a predicate (
) and a
array, use

code: let contacts = try store.unifiedContacts(matching: predicate, keysToFetch: keysToFetch)

inlineContent.text: The Contacts framework can also perform operations on the fetched contacts, such as formatting contact names. Each operation requires a specific set of contact keys to correctly perform the operation. The contact keys are key descriptor objects that you need to include within the
array. For example, if you want to fetch the contact’s email addresses and also be able to format the contact’s name (using
), include both
and the key descriptor object that
returns in the
array.
Users can grant or deny access to contact data on a per-app basis. Any call to
blocks the app while asking the user to grant or deny access. Note that the user receives a prompt only the first time an app requests access; all subsequent
calls use the existing permissions. To avoid having your app’s UI main thread block for this access, you can use either the asynchronous method
or dispatch your
usage to a background thread.
An iOS app linked on or after iOS 10 needs to include in its
file the usage description keys for the types of data it needs to access or it crashes. To access Contacts data specifically, it needs to include

A partial contact results when the system fetches only some of a contact object’s properties from a contact store. All fetched contact objects are partial contacts. If you try to access a property value that the system didn’t fetch, you get an exception. If you are unsure which keys the system fetched in the contact, check the availability of the property values before you access them. You can either use
to check the availability of a single contact key, or
to check multiple keys. If the desired keys aren’t available, refetch the contact with them.

code: // Check whether the phone number is available for the given contact.
let refetchedContact = try store.unifiedContact(withIdentifier: contact.identifier, keysToFetch: keysToFetch)

inlineContent.text: You can automatically link contacts in different accounts that represent the same person. Linked contacts display in macOS and iOS apps as unified contacts. A unified contact is an in-memory, temporary view of the set of linked contacts that the system merges into one contact.
By default the Contacts framework returns unified contacts. Each fetched unified contact object (
) has its own unique identifier that’s different from any individual contact’s identifier in the set of linked contacts. When refetching a unified contact, be sure to use its identifier.
The contact store (
) also saves changes to the Contacts framework objects. The

class enables save operations and allows batching of changes to multiple contacts and groups into a single operation. After adding all objects to the save request, it can execute with a contact store as the code example below shows. Don’t access the objects in the save request while the save is executing, because the objects may have modifications.
isn’t available in watchOS.
Create and save a new contact.
Modify and save an existing contact.

code: // Update the home email address for John Appleseed.
guard let mutableContact = contact.mutableCopy() as? CNMutableContact else { return }
let newEmail = CNLabeledValue(label: CNLabelHome, value: "john@example.com" as NSString)

inlineContent.text: After successfully executing a save, the contact store posts a

notification to the default notification center. If you cache any Contacts framework objects, you need to refetch those objects, either by their identifiers, or with the predicates that you used to originally fetch them, and then release the cached objects. Note that cached objects are stale, but not invalid.

A user may have contacts in their device’s local account or server accounts that they configure to sync contacts. Each account has at least one container of contacts. A contact can be in only one container.

A group is a set of contacts within a container. Not all accounts support groups, and some accounts also support subgroups. An iCloud account has only one container and may have many groups, but no subgroups. An Exchange account doesn’t support groups, but may have multiple containers representing Exchange folders.

abstract.text: Access the user’s contacts, and format and localize contact information.
An object that represents a user adding a contact.
An object that represents a user adding a group.
An object that represents a user adding a contact to a group.
An object that represents a user adding a subgroup to a group.
An object that represents a user deleting a contact.
An object that represents a user deleting a group.
An object that indicates the delegate should drop all contacts and groups before handling change events.
An object that represents the user adding, updating, or deleting a contact or group.
An interface for receiving notice of changes to contacts and groups.
An object that specifies the criteria for fetching change history.
An object that represents a user removing a contact from a group.
An object that represents a user removing a subgroup from a group.
An object that represents a user updating a contact.
An object that represents an updated group event.
An immutable object that stores information about a single contact, such as the contact’s first name, phone numbers, and addresses.
Determines whether all contact property values for the specified keys are fetched.
Determines whether the contact property value for the specified key is fetched.
Returns a predicate to find the contacts matching the specified name.
The email addresses of the contact.
An object that defines the options to use when fetching contacts.
The properties to fetch in the returned contacts.
An object that you use to format contact information before displaying it to the user.
Returns the required key descriptor for the specified formatting style of the contact.
The object that fetches and saves contacts, groups, and containers from the user’s Contacts database.
Requests access to the user’s contacts.
Fetches all unified contacts matching the specified predicate.
An object you use to convert to and from a vCard representation of the user’s contacts.
An object that defines the default options to use when displaying contacts.
The base class for contact fetch requests.
An object that represents the result of a change-history fetch request.
An immutable object that combines a contact property value with a label that describes that property.
Returns a localized string for the specified label.
A mutable object that stores information about a single contact, such as the contact’s first name, phone numbers, and addresses.
An object that you use to format a contact’s postal addresses.
An object that collects the changes you want to save to the user’s contacts database.
Returns the localized name of the property for the specified key.
Allow people to grant your app access to contact data by adding the Contact access button and Contact access picker to your app.

doc://com.apple.contacts/documentation/C.title: Accessing a person’s contact data using Contacts and ContactsUI

abstract.text: Request permission from the person to read and write their contact data.
Specify contact-related properties during fetch operations.
Access contact-related data, such as the user’s postal address and phone number.
Diagnose errors generated by the Contacts framework.
A Boolean value that indicates whether the app may access the notes in contact entries.
A message that tells the user why the app is requesting access to the user’s contacts.
An object representing a static collection of key-value pairs, for use instead of a  constant in cases that require reference semantics.
Posted when changes occur to the contact store.

media-4097924.alt: A diagram that shows two containers — one for a person’s iCloud contacts and one for that person’s social media account contacts. The iCloud container has two groups within it that each have three contacts. The two groups overlap with one contact. The social media account container has one group of two contacts in it.

media-4097926.alt: A diagram that shows two containers — one for a person’s iCloud contacts and one for that person’s social media account contacts.

media-4097927.alt: A diagram that shows the merging of a person’s iCloud and social media account contact information into a single, unified contact.

media-4097928.alt: An organizational diagram showing that a contact object has a mutable variant and can have properties that labeled value objects represent.

value.text: A static collection of objects associated with unique keys.
